terms.definition: The activity of setting up and running a business, taking on financial risks in the hope of profit.
terms.example: Starting a web design agency, opening a bakery, launching an app company

terms.definition: A way to make money alongside your primary job, often leveraging personal skills or interests.
terms.example: Freelance writing on weekends, tutoring after work, selling crafts online

terms.definition: A version of a product with just enough features to be usable by early customers and provide feedback.
terms.example: Test your idea quickly and cheaply before investing significant time or money.

terms.definition: Building a company from the ground up using personal finances and revenue‚Äîno outside investors.
terms.example: You maintain full ownership and control of your business decisions and profits.

leftPanel.title: Creating Value Through Innovation
paragraphs: Entrepreneurs identify opportunities, secure resources, and take calculated risks to create value through new products, services, or ways of doing business.
Entrepreneurship offers an alternative or complement to traditional employment‚Äîallowing you to pursue passions and create additional income streams.

highlightBox.text: � In today's economy, entrepreneurial skills are valuable even if you never start a business‚Äîthey create adaptability and resilience.

paragraphs: See problems as opportunities. Identify needs others miss.
Evaluate risks vs. rewards. Make informed decisions.
Bounce back from setbacks. Learn from failures.
Pivot when needed. Adjust based on feedback.
Find creative solutions with limited resources.
Move from idea to implementation quickly.
Constantly seek new knowledge and skills.

layoutData.title: Where Do Business Ideas Come From?
paragraphs: Successful entrepreneurs find opportunities by looking at their own experiences, skills, and observations of problems around them.
bulletPoints: Personal Experience: Problems you've encountered needing better solutions
Skills & Expertise: Areas where you have specialized knowledge
Hobbies & Interests: Activities you enjoy and understand well
Market Trends: Emerging needs or changes in consumer behavior
Technology Changes: New capabilities enabling different products
Underserved Markets: Groups whose needs aren't fully met

keyPoint.text: üí° Key Question: What problem do I see every day that I'm uniquely positioned to solve?

leftPanel.title: Not All Ideas Make Good Businesses
paragraphs: Before investing time and money, evaluate your idea using these criteria:
Problem Validation: Is there a real problem? How painful is it?
Market Size: How many people have this problem?
Feasibility: Do you have the skills and resources needed?
Profitability: Can you deliver at a price that makes profit?

infoCard.title: Also Consider:
items: Scalability: Can it grow beyond you?

layoutData.title: Diversifying Your Income Creates Security
paragraphs: Relying on a single income source is risky. Side hustles provide financial resilience and accelerate wealth building.
bulletPoints: Extra Income: Average side hustler earns $810/month additional
Debt Payoff: Use extra income to eliminate debt faster
Emergency Fund: Build financial cushion more quickly
Skills Development: Marketable experience for career growth
Business Asset: Potential to sell or scale into full-time

keyPoint.text: üí∞ $810/month invested at 8% for 30 years = $1.1 million‚Äîside hustles can fund your retirement.

leftPanel.title: Take Action: Start Small and Learn
paragraphs: 1. Market Research: Interview potential customers about their needs before building anything.
2. Create MVP: Build the simplest version that delivers value and get feedback.
3. Basic Business Plan: Outline your value proposition, target market, and revenue model.
4. Start Small: Serve a few customers, document what works, then gradually expand.
